post_title: Research team develops reconfigurable photonic computing architecture for lifelong learning
title: Photonic Lifelong Learning for Real-Life AI Applications at Scale
post_content:
Title: Photonic Lifelong Learning for Real-Life AI Applications

Introduction:
Artificial intelligence (AI) has become an integral part of our lives, and with the increase in the availability of large-scale datasets, the demand for AI-powered solutions has grown exponentially. However, the current AI models are limited by their energy consumption and computational limitations. The need for next-generation computing modalities has led to the development of photonic computing, which promises better energy efficiency, processing speed, and computational throughput.

Body:
Photonic computing is a promising avenue for AI applications that requires the development of reconfigurable photonic computing architectures for lifelong learning. Existing photonic neural networks (ONNs) suffer from "catastrophic forgetting" and struggle with simple onefold tasks due to the limitations of conventional computing systems. These limitations prevent ONNs from fully exploiting the intrinsic properties of sparsity and parallelism in photonic computing.

The team of scientists, led by Professor Lu Fang from Sigma Laboratory, Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, co-workers have developed L2ONN, a reconfigurable photonic computing architecture for lifelong learning. The unique characteristics of light, spatial sparsity, and multi-spectrum parallelism have been developed in photonic computing architecture for the first time, endowing ONNs with lifelong learning capability. Unlike existing ONNs that try to imitate artificial neural networks (ANNs), L2ONN follows the physical nature of light-matter interaction, to fully explore the functional and performance potentials of wave optics in photonic computing.

Experimental evaluations on free-space and on-chip architectures demonstrate that L2ONN shows its extraordinary learning capability on challenging tens-of-tasks, such as vision classification, voice recognition, and medical diagnosis, supporting various new environments. L2ONN achieves up to 14 times larger capacity than existing optical neural networks, with an order of magnitude higher energy efficiency than the representative electronic artificial neural networks.

Conclusion:
Humans possess the unique ability to incrementally absorb, learn, and memorize knowledge. This ability is due to the sparse neuron connectivity and parallelly task-driven neurocognition mechanisms that contribute to lifelong memory consolidation and retrieval. Similarly, in ONNs, these characteristic features can be naturally promoted from biological neurons to photonic neurons based on the intrinsic sparsity and parallelism properties of optical operators. An optical architecture imitating the structure and function of human brains demonstrates its potential to alleviate the issues mentioned above, which shows more advantages than electronic approaches in constructing a viable lifelong learning computing system.

The proposed photonic lifelong learning provides a turnkey solution for large-scale real-life AI applications with unprecedented scalability and versatility. The proposed neuromorphic architecture will accelerate the development of more powerful photonic computing as critical support for modern advanced machine intelligence, leading to the beginning of a new era of AI.

Title: US and EU Join Forces to Combat Harmful Chemicals in Chipmaking Using AI

Introduction

In a significant development for the tech industry, the US government plans to collaborate with the European Union on an Artificial Intelligence (AI) initiative. The primary objective of this partnership is to eliminate harmful chemicals, particularly polyfluorinated substances (PFAS), from the chipmaking process. This move comes as part of broader negotiations at the US-EU Trade and Technology Council meetings in Belgium.

The PFAS Problem

PFAS, also known as "forever chemicals," have been used in semiconductor manufacturing for years. These substances are nearly impossible to break down and often end up in the products humans use and consume. Consequently, PFAS have been discovered in a wide range of tech devices, food, and even in human bodies. This poses potential health risks and contributes to pollution worldwide.

The US and EU's Joint Efforts

The US and the EU aim to identify research cooperation opportunities that could lead to alternatives for the use of PFAS in chip manufacturing. They plan to leverage AI capabilities and digital twins to expedite the discovery of suitable materials to replace PFAS in semiconductor manufacturing. The use of AI can help analyze vast amounts of data and predict potential outcomes, making it an invaluable tool in this endeavor.

The China Factor

One of the driving factors behind this initiative is the concern over China's heavy investment in mature semiconductor production. These chips, while not as powerful as their newer counterparts, are widely used in various industries and government applications. The West fears that without new manufacturing processes, China could become the leading global supplier of mature chips, creating an international security issue.

Addressing the PFAS Usage

The US-EU statement, however, lacks specifics on how exactly AI will be used to address the PFAS problem and how long it will take to implement the solution. The statement does mention that the countries intend to collect and share non-confidential information, consult each other on planned actions, and potentially develop joint or cooperative measures to address distortionary effects on the global supply chain for legacy semiconductors.

Conclusion

The collaboration between the US and the EU to eliminate harmful chemicals from the chipmaking process marks a significant step forward in the tech industry.

post_title: Jobs for the Future's new $50M fund looks to invest in underrepresented founders
title: JFFVentures Fund II: Investing in underrepresented founders for economic mobility
post_content:
Are you tired of dealing with tedious tasks and endless paperwork? Do you want to take your business to the next level but lack the resources to do so? If so, Jobs for the Future's (JFF) new $50M fund may be the solution to your problems.

JFFVentures, the venture arm of JFF, has recently launched its second fund - JFFVentures Fund II. This fund aims to invest in underrepresented founders building HR, education, and workforce solutions that enable economic mobility for workers in middle to low-wage jobs.

JFFVentures Fund II has already raised $15 million, and its target is to raise an additional $35 million, bringing the total fund size to $50 million. The fund will invest in 30 to 35 pre-seed and seed-stage startups, with initial check sizes ranging from $250,000 to $1 million, with the ability to lead rounds. The fund will also reserve $1 million to $2 million for follow-on investments into companies that are performing well financially and impact-wise.

JFFVentures Fund II is not the first impact-focused venture fund in the US. Collaborative Fund, Third Sphere, and the nonprofit Acumen Fund are also examples of venture funds that aim to drive social, economic, and environmental change while earning investment returns. However, impact funds face challenges that traditional startup venture funds do not, such as measuring the real-world impact of investments and offering lower returns.

To overcome these challenges, JFFVentures Fund II will benefit from the wider JFF community, including its connections with government, corporate, education, and nonprofit partners. Founders in Fund II will have access to at least one dedicated person who can connect them with experts and networks across the JFF ecosystem.

JFFVentures Fund II's top priority is economic advancement for the underserved and underrepresented populations. The fund aims to invest in solutions that will empower women, disabled workers, immigrants, aging populations, and communities of color. JFFVentures has committed in its fund documents that at least 50% of Fund II founders will identify as underrepresented in terms of founder backgrounds. Additionally, part of the team has been allocated carry, which will be earned by hitting certain social impact goals.

While the 2021 study from Cambridge Associates found that impact venture funds tend to underperform, JFFVentures' inaugural fund performance serves as evidence that Fund II can succeed. post_title: Game theory research shows AI can evolve into more selfish or cooperative personalities
title: Evolving AI Personality Using LLMs: A Revolutionary Approach to AI Research
post_content:
Introducing a Revolutionary Approach to Developing AI Personality: Large-Scale Language Models

In recent years, AI systems have become increasingly adept at mimicking human behavior, but their personalities remain limited to predetermined traits. In a groundbreaking study, Professor Takaya Arita and Associate Professor Reiji Suzuki from Nagoya University's Graduate School of Informatics have developed a framework for evolving AI agents that exhibit a diverse range of personality traits using large-scale language models (LLMs). Their findings, published in Scientific Reports, provide fascinating insights into the role of language in shaping AI personality and hint at the transformative potential of LLMs in AI research.

The study focused on developing a framework for evolving AI agents that could switch between selfish and cooperative actions, adapting their strategies through evolutionary processes. The researchers used the prisoner's dilemma from game theory as a starting point, creating a game in which both AI systems must choose whether to cooperate or defect from each other. If both agree to cooperate, they receive four virtual dollars, but if one defects while the other cooperates, the defector earns five dollars, and the cooperator earns nothing. If both defect, they receive one dollar each.

The researchers used LLMs to evolve prompts that encouraged more diverse personality traits during social interactions. By utilizing the remarkable capabilities of LLMs, they developed a framework where AI agents evolved based on natural language descriptions of personality traits encoded in their genes. Through this framework, they observed various types of personality traits, with the evolution of AIs capable of switching between selfish and cooperative behaviors, reflecting human behavior.

The study used an evolutionary framework, in which AI agents' abilities were shaped by natural selection and mutation over generations. This caused a wide range of personality traits to appear. Although some agents displayed selfish characteristics, prioritizing their own interests over those of the community or the group as a whole, other agents demonstrated advanced strategies that revolved around seeking personal gain while still considering mutual and collective benefit.

The researchers also discovered the instability inherent in AI societies, with excessively cooperative groups being replaced by more "egocentric" agents. This achievement underscores the transformative potential of LLMs in AI research, showing that the evolution of personality traits based on subtle linguistic expressions can be represented by a computational model using LLMs.

The findings of this study provide insights into the characteristics that AI agents should possess to contribute to human society, as well as design guidelines for AI societies and societies with mixed AI and human populations, which are expected to arrive in the not-too-distant future. In conclusion, the study highlights the importance of language in shaping AI personalities and the transformative potential of LLMs in AI research. By utilizing the remarkable capabilities of LLMs, we can develop AI agents that exhibit a diverse range of personality traits and contribute to human society.

post_title: Scientists develop novel amorphous flexible mini-inductor
title: Amorphous Flexible Mini-Inductor: A Novel Approach to Miniaturized Electronics
post_content:
INTRODUCTION

In today's world, the demand for miniaturized and energy-efficient electronic devices is increasing rapidly. To meet this demand, researchers have been exploring new materials and technologies to improve device performance, reduce energy consumption, and achieve miniaturization. One such material that has shown promising results in recent years is amorphous alloys.

Amorphous alloys are a type of material that lacks long-range atomic order, making them highly flexible and adaptable to various applications. In the field of electronics, amorphous alloys have been used to create flexible inductors, which are key components in power conversion and signal processing. In this article, we will explore the development of a new amorphous flexible mini-inductor by a research team at the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering (NIMTE) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

BODY

Flexible mini-inductors are essential in improving the performance of electronic devices, as they allow for greater energy density and reduced size. However, conventional coils made of non-magnetic materials inevitably cause magnetic leakage, which reduces the inductance density and makes them unsuitable for low-frequency applications.

To overcome this problem, Prof. Wang Junqiang and his team at NIMTE used Fe-based soft magnetic amorphous alloys as coil materials to fabricate an amorphous flexible mini-inductor. This novel device achieved both excellent flexibility and high inductance, making it ideal for low-frequency applications.

The team used high-precision femtosecond laser ablation technology to craft amorphous alloy ribbons without inducing the crystallization of the amorphous alloys, while maintaining their intrinsic mechanical excellence. This technique allowed for the fabrication of a mini-inductor with a high permeability and low magnetic leakage, making it ideal for applications where interference between electronic components must be minimized.

The developed amorphous flexible mini-inductor had an inductance density of about 280â€“390 nH/mm2, which is about 10 times higher than that of conventional planar inductors. Moreover, it could be stretched by 300% of its original size and maintain its performance after 2,500 bending cycles at a 16-mm bending radius. This superior stability and flexibility made it ideal for various bending and folding application environments.

The amorphous flexible mini-inductor also had a miniaturization advantage, as it could achieve high inductance density in a very small volume. This feature made it suitable for use in thin and light electronic products, such as wearable devices and smart sensors.

CONCLUSION

The development of the amorphous flexible mini-inductor by Prof. Wang Junqiang and his team at NIMTE represents a significant advancement in the field of flexible electronics. This novel device not only achieves high inductance density and flexibility but also has excellent stability and adaptability to various application environments.

The use of high-precision femtosecond laser ablation technology to fabricate the amorphous alloy ribbons without inducing crystallization is a promising approach that opens up new possibilities for the development of flexible electronics.

This study not only provides a new application scenario for amorphous soft magnetic alloys but also sheds light on the material selection and device design of flexible electronics technology. As the demand for miniaturized and energy-efficient electronic devices continues to grow, the development of new materials and technologies, such as the amorphous flexible mini-inductor, will play a crucial role in meeting these demands.

post_title: Proof-of-principle demonstration of 3D magnetic recording could lead to enhanced hard disk drives
title: 3D Magnetic Recording Breakthrough: Boosting HDD Storage Capacity
post_content:
Title: A Breakthrough in Data Storage: The Emergence of 3D Magnetic Recording

In a groundbreaking development for the field of hard disk drives (HDD), research groups from NIMS, Seagate Technology, and Tohoku University have successfully demonstrated the viability of multi-level recording using a three-dimensional magnetic recording medium. This innovation paves the way for increased storage capacity in HDDs, leading to more efficient and cost-effective data storage solutions.

The current landscape of data centers is filled with hard disk drives relying on perpendicular magnetic recording (PMR) to store information at areal densities of approximately 1.5 Tbit/inÂ². However, to transition to higher areal densities, a high anisotropy magnetic recording medium consisting of FePt grains combined with heat-assisted laser writing is required. Enter heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), a method that can maintain areal recording densities of up to 10 Tbit/inÂ², with the potential for densities larger than 10 Tbit/inÂ² based on a new principle that stores multiple recording levels of 3 or 4, compared to the binary level used in HDD technology.

In their study, published in Acta Materialia, the research team successfully arranged the FePt recording layers three-dimensionally. They achieved this by fabricating lattice-matched, FePt/Ru/FePt multilayer films, with Ru acting as a spacer layer. Measurements of the magnetization revealed that the two FePt layers have different Curie temperatures, enabling three-dimensional recording through laser power adjustment when writing.

The researchers also demonstrated the 3D recording principle through recording simulations, using a media model that mirrors the microstructure and magnetic properties of the fabricated media. This method has the potential to increase recording capacity by stacking recording layers in three dimensions, allowing for more digital information storage within fewer HDDs, and consequently, energy savings for data centers.

To further advance this technology, the researchers aim to develop processes to reduce the size of FePt grains, enhance orientation and magnetic anisotropy, and stack more FePt layers to create a media structure suitable for practical use in high-density HDDs. This breakthrough in 3D magnetic recording promises a significant leap in data storage capacity, making it an exciting development to watch

Rooms, a three-dimensional interior design app created by ex-Google employees, has just released a significant update to its iOS app. The app's new features include an activity feed, an explore page, the ability to browse by category, and more. Rooms has grown its user base to over a quarter of a million registered users since its launch in November 2023.

Rooms allows players to create and customize intricate 3D rooms using a library of over 7,500 digital items. Users can edit the code with Lua, a programming language used in Roblox Studio. The app's founders, Jason Toff, Bruno Oliveira, and Nick Kruge, have experience working at Uber, YouTube, and Smule, respectively.

The Activity tab allows creators to track likes and comments, along with when their room is "remixed" or posted. The Remix feature has been updated to detect copycat rooms. Under the hood, the team implemented a mesh optimization method to make large rooms render up to 20 times faster.

This new PCAM device can potentially replace existing memory technologies, such as DRAM and NAND flash memory, and pave the way for neuromorphic computing in next-generation artificial intelligence hardware.

The Challenges of Conventional Phase Change Memory

Conventional phase change memory has faced several challenges, including an expensive fabrication process for highly scaled devices and high power consumption during operation. These issues have hindered the development of practical large-capacity memory products and the realization of neuromorphic computing systems. Although previous research efforts focused on reducing power consumption by shrinking the physical size of the device, these attempts were limited by increased fabrication costs and complexity.

Professor Choi's team developed the Nano-Filament-based Phase Change Memory (NFPCM), a novel approach to solving the problems associated with conventional phase change memory. The NFPCM features an ultra-low power consumption phase change memory device that consumes 15 times less power than a conventional device fabricated with an expensive lithography tool.

The NFPCM operates by electrically forming a highly confined BEC (bipolar electronic conduction) to reduce the reset current. This is achieved by creating a very small nanometer (nm) scale phase changeable filament without relying on expensive fabrication processes. The simplicity of this approach results in a device with both low processing costs and ultra-low power consumption.

post_title: Microsoft may have finally made quantum computing useful
title: Microsoft's Quantum Breakthrough: 800x Lower Error Rate
post_content:
Quantum computing has been an exhilarating prospect for years, but despite claims from tech giants like IBM, Google, and Microsoft, practical applications of the technology have remained elusive. Today, Microsoft and Quantinuum announced that they have developed the most error-free quantum computing system yet, a breakthrough that could finally pave the way for practical quantum computing.

Unlike classical computers, which rely on binary bits, quantum computers operate with qubits that can exist in a superposition of two states simultaneously. While this allows quantum computers to perform certain calculations exponentially faster than classical computers, it also makes them prone to errors. This is why today's quantum computers, known as NISQ computers, are only used for research and experimentation.

Microsoft's solution was to group physical qubits into virtual qubits, allowing it to apply error diagnostics and correction without destroying them. This resulted in an error rate that was 800 times better than relying on physical qubits alone. Microsoft claims it was able to run over 14,000 experiments without any errors.

According to Jason Zander, EVP of Microsoft's Strategic Missions and Technologies division, this achievement could finally bring us to "Level 2 Resilient" quantum computing, which would be reliable enough for practical applications. "The task at hand for the entire quantum ecosystem is to increase the fidelity of qubits and enable fault-tolerant quantum computing so that we can use a quantum machine to unlock solutions to previously intractable problems," Zander wrote in a blog post.

Microsoft's announcement was met with enthusiasm from experts in the field, with Professor Aram Harrow of MIT calling the achievement a "strong result." "The Quantinuum system has impressive error rates and control, so it was plausible that they could do an experiment like this, but it's encouraging to see that it worked," Harrow wrote in an email to Engadget.

Microsoft's Azure Quantum Elements will soon be available as a private preview, allowing researchers to get a taste of reliable quantum computing. The goal is to push even further to Level 3 quantum supercomputing, which could theoretically tackle incredibly complex issues like climate change and exotic drug research. However, it's unclear how long it will take to actually reach that point.

Professor Harrow cautioned that getting to a large-scale fault-tolerant quantum computer is still a long road, but the progress made on cold atom platforms has been impressive. "This is an important step for this hardware platform," Harrow wrote. "Along with the progress on neutral atoms, it means that the cold atom platforms are doing very well relative to their superconducting qubit competitors."

In conclusion, Microsoft's breakthrough in developing the most error-free quantum computing system yet is a significant step towards practical quantum computing. With the launch of Azure Quantum Elements, researchers will be able to experiment with reliable quantum computing, paving the way for even more advancements in the future. While the task of achieving large-scale fault-tolerant quantum computing is still a long road, this achievement marks a crucial milestone in the development of this exciting technology.

Setting up a new device is an exciting process, but it's also a time of uncertainty when it comes to privacy. A recent study from Aalto University sheds light on the privacy settings of Apple's default apps, the ones that are an integral part of the platform and ecosystem.

The researchers studied eight apps: Safari, Siri, Family Sharing, iMessage, FaceTime, Location Services, Find My, and Touch ID. They collected all publicly available privacy-related information on these apps, from technical documentation to privacy policies and user manuals.

The study revealed that users don't know what is going on when it comes to privacy settings, even with apps that are an integral part of the platform. For example, users are given the option to enable or disable Siri, Apple's virtual assistant. However, enabling only refers to whether they use Siri's voice control. Siri collects data in the background from other apps they use, regardless of their choice, unless they understand how to go into the settings and specifically change that.

Participants in the study were not able to stop data sharing in any of the apps. The instructions for restricting data access were complex and confusing, with the necessary steps scattered in different places. There was no clear direction on whether to go to the app settings, central settings, or both. Additionally, the instructions did not list all the necessary steps or explain how collected data is processed.

The researchers also demonstrated these problems experimentally. They interviewed users and asked them to try changing the settings. The participants were not able to prevent any of the apps from sharing their data with other applications or the service provider.

The study suggests that Apple could inform users much more clearly than it does today. They could provide detailed suggestions to clarify privacy settings and improve guidelines. For individual apps, the problem can be solved to some extent by opting for a third-party service.

In conclusion, setting up a new device requires persistent and expert clicking on each app individually. Apple's help falls short when it comes to privacy settings, which can make it difficult for users to protect their privacy on the platform. It's essential to be aware of the privacy settings of default apps and to make informed choices about the data they share.

The Gulf Coast of the United States is no stranger to tropical cyclones, hurricanes, and other extreme weather events. These phenomena can cause widespread electricity outages, with the risk of such events only increasing due to climate change and global warming. A recent study by researchers at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research (PIK) and Fraunhofer SCAI in Germany focused on the Texas power grid, aiming to identify the lines that should be reinforced to prevent serious outages in the future.

In their research, published in Nature Energy, the team compared two models for prioritizing power lines in need of hardening: a static model and a co-evolution model. The static model assigned priority based on factors such as line length, voltage, and the number of customers served, while the co-evolution model considered the dynamic interplay between evolving storm conditions and the partially destroyed state of the grid.

The researchers found that the co-evolution model provided a more accurate representation of the system, as it took into account the temporal-spatial structure of damages and outages, a topic with little preexisting research. By understanding the interplay between evolving storm conditions and the grid's damaged state, the team was better able to identify critical lines whose failure would most likely trigger large-scale blackouts.

This study highlights the importance of considering the historical context of damages when assessing a power grid's resilience. As every transmission line failure changes the topology and dynamics of the grid, the grid's response to future adverse weather events depends on the history of previous damages. By identifying the failure modes of complex but robust systems, the researchers aimed to prevent catastrophic failures and reinforce the "backbone" of the grid, ultimately enhancing its resilience against extreme wind events.

To increase the grid's resilience, the team suggests focusing on enhancing the resilience of critical lines identified by their models. This could be achieved by replacing overhead lines with underground cables, which offer better protection against wind damage. This method, however, should be carefully considered, as underground cables come with their own set of challenges, such as higher installation costs and limited repair capabilities during outages.

This move comes after the tech giant abandoned its electric car project and ramped up efforts in the AI space.

The rumored home robots encompass a mobile robot assistant that navigates around users' homes and an advanced tabletop device with a motorized display powered by robotics. post_title: Researchers find a simple way to harvest more 'blue energy' from waves
title: "Optimized TENG Captures 2.4x More 'Blue Energy' from Waves"
post_content:
If you've ever watched a surfer ride the waves, you know just how much power they possess. Now, scientists are one step closer to capturing the energy behind the ocean's constant ebb and flow with an improved "blue energy" harvesting device. Researchers have developed a liquid-solid triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) that converts mechanical energy into electricity as water sloshes back and forth against the inside of a tube.

The TENG's electrode was originally placed at the center of the tube, but the researchers optimized the device's conversion of mechanical energy to electrical current by moving the electrode to the end where the water crashes with the most force. This new design increased the TENG's energy harvesting ability by 2.4 times.

The researchers conducted two experiments to demonstrate the potential of the device. In the first, they placed two TENGs on a benchtop and moved water back and forth within the tubes. The TENGs generated electrical currents by converting the friction from water hitting or sliding against the electrodes into electricity. In the second experiment, the TENG blinked an array of 35 LEDs on and off as water entered the section of the tube covered by the electrode and then flowed away.

The researchers say these demonstrations lay the foundation for larger-scale blue-energy harvesting from ocean waves and show the device's potential for other applications like wireless underwater signaling communications.

In summary, the researchers have optimized the conversion of mechanical energy to electrical current in a liquid-solid TENG by moving the electrode to the end of the tube where the water crashes with the most force. The new design increased the TENG's energy harvesting ability by 2.4 times, making it a promising device for capturing the energy behind the ocean's constant ebb and flow.

post_title: Tech companies want to build artificial general intelligence. But who decides when AGI is attained?
title: Build AGI, but who decides its attainment? Tech companies aim to create a thinking machine, but risks and challenges persist. AGI's definition remains elusive, and the debate continues on how to measure it.
post_content:
Are we ready to build a machine that can think and act like a human? That's the ambitious goal of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), a futuristic concept that's been gaining traction in the tech industry. AGI is a broadly smart machine that can perform a wide range of tasks, from reasoning and planning to learning from experiences.

The race to build AGI is on, and tech giants like Amazon, Google, Meta, and Microsoft are investing heavily in this cutting-edge technology. However, AGI is not without its risks. Experts warn that unchecked AGIs with long-term planning skills could pose an existential threat to humanity.

While AGI is a buzzword that's constantly being redefined, it's not a technical term. Geoffrey Hinton, a pioneering AI scientist, prefers the term "superintelligence" for AGIs that are better than humans. However, AGI is a serious concept, and there is no clear definition of what it means.

Mainstream AI research has turned away from the original vision of artificial intelligence, which was once an ambitious idea. Pei Wang, a professor who teaches an AGI course at Temple University, explains that the 'G' in AGI was a signal to those who still want to do the big thing. They don't want to build tools; they want to build a thinking machine.

So, are we at AGI yet? Without a clear definition, it's hard to know when a company or group of researchers will have achieved AGI. However, some experts believe that AGI is a matter of when, not if. Improvements in autoregressive AI techniques and massive computing power have led to impressive chatbots, but they're not quite the AGI that many people had in mind.

To measure AGI, some researchers are working towards consensus on how to classify it. Others are planning to figure it out on their own, like OpenAI, which has given its nonprofit board of directors the responsibility of deciding when its AI systems have reached the point at which they "outperform humans at most economically valuable work."

In conclusion, AGI is a challenging yet exciting concept that has the potential to revolutionize the way we think about machines. While there are risks associated with AGI, the benefits of a thinking machine are too great to ignore. As we continue to push the boundaries of AI, it's crucial that we approach AGI with caution and careful consideration for its implications on humanity.

post_title: The new Google search powered by next-gen AI may be subscription-only
title: Google Mulls Paid Search Tier with Generative AI Features in Google One
post_content:
Title: Google's Potential Shift: A Paid Search Tier Powered by Generative AI

Google, the search engine giant, has built its empire on a free platform that has dominated the market for decades. However, with the increasing threat of new generative AI models, Google is preparing to revolutionize its business model.

According to a Financial Times report, Google is contemplating introducing a paywall to access premium generative AI features in its search engine. Under this plan, these advanced AI-powered search features would be added to Google's premium subscription service, Google One. Although engineers are working on the technology, Google executives have not yet decided when or if the paywall will be implemented.

Launched in February, Google One costs $20 per month and currently offers various perks such as 2TB of storage, Google Photos editing features, Google Store rewards, Google Meet premium video calling features, and Google Calendar enhanced appointment scheduling. Google's traditional search engine would remain free and ad-supported. However, the introduction of a paid search tier would mark a significant shift in Google's business model, which has kept its search engine free since its inception over two decades ago.

The primary reason for this potential change is the high cost of deploying and maintaining generative AI features on its search engine. However, there is no guarantee that people would be interested in such an AI-assisted search service, especially with numerous free competitors available. For instance, ChatGPT recently made access to its free chatbot easier by eliminating logins, allowing users to ask questions directly on the site.

Although Google has a distinct advantage as it doesn't have a knowledge cutoff, ChatGPT can still be an attractive option for users seeking information about topics before January 2022. Microsoft's Copilot is another strong competitor, offering conversationally based answers, access to the latest information, and no knowledge cutoff, all for free.

Despite the possibility of some of Google's AI-infused search features being behind a paywall soon, users can sign up for the Search Generative Experience (SGE) to experience Google's AI-infused search engine for free. Simply visit Search Labs and log in with your Google account.

In conclusion, Google's potential move towards a paid search tier could be a game-changer for the tech giant
